A function to compute fold power increase (FPI)

Source: R/FPI.R
getFPI.DNAStringSet.Rd

This function takes a set of sequences and a k-mer of interest, along with a given period. It calculates the FPI, as introduced by Pich et al., Cell 2018.

# S3 method for DNAStringSet
getFPI(
  x,
  motif,
  period = 10,
  order = 1,
  n_shuffling = 10,
  cores_shuffling = 1,
  cores_computing = 1,
  verbose = 1,
  ...
)

Arguments

x

DNAStringSet, sequences of interest
motif

character, k-mer of interest
period

integer, Period of interest
order

Integer, which order to take into consideration for shuffling (ushuffle python library must be installed for orders > 1)
n_shuffling

integer, Number of shuffling
cores_shuffling

integer, Number of cores used for shuffling
cores_computing

integer, split the workload over several processors using BiocParallel
verbose

integer, Should the function be verbose?
...

Additional arguments

Value

Several metrics including FPI, observed PSD, etc...

Details

The FPI is calculated as the ratio of the observed k-mer PSD at the chosen perdiod subtracted by the median k-mer PSD in shuffled sequences, divided by the median k-mer PSD in shuffled sequences. The number of shufflings is specified by the n_shuffling argument.

Examples

data(ce11_proms_seqs)
BiocParallel::register(setUpBPPARAM(1))
fpi <- getFPI(
    ce11_proms_seqs[1:10],
    motif = 'TT'
)
#> - Calculating observed PSD
#> - Mapping k-mers.
#> - 12945 pairwise distances measured.
#> - Calculating pairwise distance distribution.
#> - Normalizing histogram vector.
#> - Applying Fast Fourier Transform to the vector of distances.
#> >> Measured PSD @ 10bp is: 4.78946534620361e-06
#> - Shuffling 1/10
#> - Shuffling 2/10
#> - Shuffling 3/10
#> - Shuffling 4/10
#> - Shuffling 5/10
#> - Shuffling 6/10
#> - Shuffling 7/10
#> - Shuffling 8/10
#> - Shuffling 9/10
#> - Shuffling 10/10
#> >> Calculated FPI @ 10bp is: 6.75227346511369
#> Only 10 shufflings. Cannot compute accurate empirical p-values. To compute empirical p-values, set up n_shuffling to at least 100. Only FPI is returned
fpi$FPI
#> [1] 6.752273
fpi$observed_PSD
#> [1] 4.789465e-06
fpi$shuffled_PSD
#>  [1] 1.318074e-06 1.940373e-08 7.934358e-07 2.434129e-08 7.056279e-07
#>  [6] 4.067809e-07 1.214519e-06 9.477562e-07 5.300007e-07 2.852541e-07
plotFPI(fpi)
